bug.short_desc: Can't use custom command line for ieapp

long_desc.thetext:
I have to start Internet Explorer with a custom command line because I need to run it with Japanese system locale (using an MS tool called app switcher).
I'm trying to use the following commandline: C:\WINDOWS\AppPatch\AppLoc.exe "C:\Program Files\Internet Explorer\IEXPLORE.EXE" "/L0411".
This works fine in a DOS box, but not when I use it as a value in the properties of ieview. The error message is
"[Exception... "Component returned failure ccde: 0x80520001 (NS_ERROR_FILE_UNRECOGNIZED_PATH) [nsILocalFile.initWithPath]" nsresult:
"0x80520001 (NS_ERROR_FILE_UNRECOGNIZED_PATH)" location: "JS frame :: chrome://ieview/content/ieviewOverlay.js :: ieViewLaunch :: line 265" data: no"
At the moment I use a batch file with my command line as work around.
Thanks, Claus
I'll file this as an enhancement request -- there's a bit of scary coding involved here, to parse the app name out from the parameters. Your batch file approach is the best workaround for now.

The problem is that the URL parameter mustn't appended to the end but instead in the middle of the command line. This is in my batch file:
start C:\WINDOWS\AppPatch\AppLoc.exe "C:\Program Files\Internet Explorer\IEXPLORE.EXE" "%1" "/L0411"
I think the best solution would be to define a place holder for the URL that can be used in the command line. Something like "iexplore.exe ${URL}". Then everybody can build it's own command.

Hi,
I'm wondering if it's possible to run IE with minimised security priveleges, since I don't trust it. You will find the following link very helpful
http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/en-us/dncode/html/secure11152004.asp
The above link is a program (Drop My Rights) written by a MS security expert to allow you to run any program with reduced priveleges. There is source code that you might be able to use to directly integrate this into IE View without the third party software. You could put a tickbox in the options.
I'm currently using "Drop My Rights" in all of my own Windows XP shortcuts, so that all my net programs have reduced priveleges, but when I try to integrate it into the IE View extension, it says "Unable to locate Internet Explorer". I insert the IE location into IE View as "C:\Program Files\Security\DropMyRights\DropMyRights.exe C:\Program Files\Internet Explorer\IEXPLORE.EXE" - have also tried with inverted commas around each path separately, but with no joy.
Thanks for checking this out,
Mike Pittman.

This has come up before. IE View takes the entire string you enter as the IE location, and tries to execute that "filename" as a program. Obviously, the program + parameters command line doesn't work well in this situation.
In the meantime, your best bet is probably to create a batch file, along the lines of:
"C:\Program Files\Security\DropMyRights\DropMyRights.exe" "C:\Program Files\Internet Explorer\IEXPLORE.EXE" %1 %2 %3 %4
And point IE View at *that*.

Hi Paul,
Thanks - that works perfectly. It did cross my mind, but I thought it was a long shot. I should have tried.
I've also changed my primary login from admin to non-admin, and run only what needs to be admin that way using "Run As" from the context (right-click) menu (can be run from the command line also with many options). Having said that, I'm still interested in restricting IE completely if possible, so could you still look into this if it's not too hard?
I'm sure that 95% of Windows XP users default to admin, as I did - and they reckon XP SP2 is so secure! Perhaps restricting IE should be the default for IEview, with a button to remove the restriction?

That would actually require some significant windows-only code changes to Firefox itself; it's not something that can be done at IE View's level.
Of course, if *Firefox* were running at a non-admin level, I believe and IE instance it spawned would run that way as well.

What I was thinking was something much simpler. It seems to me (a non-programmer, but have worked in IT support) that IEview must make some system call to spawn IE. The idea with the DropMyRights software is that such system calls attach a "token" with restricted priveleges (restricted tokens work from Windows XP/2003 on). So I was thinking that IEview could do its normal system call to spawn IE, but attach such a token to that call. In my understanding this shouldn't require any changes to Firefox, only to the system call made by IEview.
The link in my original email has the source code (seems to be C#) for "DropMyRights". It seems that similar code could be easily added to IEview.
Platform compatibility shouldn't be a great problem, since people would most often use this in Windows. But if it is a problem, it shouldn't be too hard to check the OS and only add the token if it's Windows XP/2003 or greater.
I have tested running DropMyRights and IEview (referring to the batch file - see above), logged in as Admin, and it spawns IE as a non-admin user - tested by trying to save a file to the admin home directory. This was on the basic restriction, but the tighter restrictions will also block access to the windows registry and the normal user's home directory completely so that nothing can be written to disk at all.

(In reply to comment #4) > What I was thinking was something much simpler. It seems to me (a > non-programmer, but have worked in IT support) that IEview must make some system > call to spawn IE.
Nope. IE View calls a javascript function in Firefox, and Firefox launches the program. So FF is where the changes would be needed.

I've actually realised that the batch file doesn't work. I only tested it using my home page, but it doesn't seem to be passing the website details on to IE. I've removed the batch file link and am just running in a non-admin login now to solve the security problem.
I still can't understand how, even if you're calling a javascript function, that some other variables cannot be passed along with the call. I would guess there's already at least one variable being passed - the site link.
In any case, I think you understand a lot more than I do about what the internals of IEview and Firefox are and it may well be too hard at this level. If that's the case, I guess you might as well close this (or should I?). Thanks for thinking about it.

On Windows XP Professional x64 Edition (thats a mouthful) ieview spaws the 64bit version of Internet Explorer instead of the 32bit version.
My typical use of ieview is to open up a page that requires some IE specific nonsense. This usually involves an ActiveX control, Windows Media junk, etc. The problem is that, for the most part, only the 32bit version of IE can load these, and ieview spawns 64bit IE -- a crippled version of an already handicapped browser ;). So I'm stuck back with the copy URL, open IE from the start menu, paste URL method that now seems such a chore since using your wonderful extension.
The location of 32bit IE on x64 is "C:\Program Files (x86)\Internet Explorer\IEXPLORE.EXE" or "%PROGRAMFILES%\Internet Explorer\IEXPLORE.EXE" if you're using environment variables.
If there's any other information I can provide for you (since I know not that many people are running x64) please let me know.

I'll look into working around this -- we may have a problem with the fact that IE View tries to resolve shortcuts first (which may point to the 64-bit version) before it starts nosing around in directories.
As a workaround, of course, you can use the IEView Options dialog to point to the 32-bit IE.

This issue has bitten me as well, costing me a large amount of time to figure out that a resulting problem was caused by the x64 version of IE getting launched.
I think it might be best if ieview launched 32-bit IE from 32-bit Firefox, and only 64-bit IE from 64-bit Firefox (when available).
Or have ieview check for both 32-bit and 64-bit IE at first use, and ask (once) which version to use, with the choice of 32-bit IE or 64-bit IE being a simple radio-button selection in Options. (Paths aren't meaningful to most users.)
Thanks mucho for ieview! John

bug.short_desc: Closing window vs. session saving problem.

long_desc.thetext:
I have "close tab/window after loading the page" feature on. I also have auto-session-loading feature from some other extension (Tab Mix Plus). When I go in only tab I have open to some page which should always open in IE, then this closes FF. After running FF again, Tab Mix opens again that page and it again opens in IE and FF closes again. This means that manual editing of preferences file was needed to solve this situation and I had to turn "close tab/window" feature off.
I would suggest checking if the tab to be closed is the last one and if it is then not to close FF. Alternatively, it could be as an option in IEview preferences (e.g. "Close tab...." as one option and "Close FF if only one tab is open" as another"

I'll look into adding such an option. I don't see a way around it, for people who use TabMix/SessionSaver/etc. I would suggest that the TabMix saver probably should *not* save when the last open tab is a "chrome:" window (as is the case here).
Thanks for the suggestion, sorry for the inconvenience.

It could be also a TabMix problem. In fact, I want sometimes to have opened chrome: pages across sessions. I would really appreciate that option I suggested not only because it partially solves the problem, but also because closing tab is one thing and closing window is quite another. I am used not to close FF during the day, for example.
But I understand that I am only one user out of many happy users.
Another good solution could be to remove "close window" feature (or remove it only for links opened in IE automatically) and leave only close tab there (if tab is last one, then it wont be closed).
Sorry for so long "wanna-be" analysis. Anyway, thanks for your work here.

(In reply to comment #2) > Another good solution could be to remove "close window" feature (or remove it
> only for links opened in IE automatically) and leave only close tab there (if > tab is last one, then it wont be closed). >
The problem there is that this feature is invoked when people double-click a link from other applications, the desktop, etc. A new Firefox (often) opens, with just the one tab, and we'd be leaving that "orphan" window around. This is exactly the reason that this feature was requested in the first place.
The answer *may* simply be that this feature is not compatible with Session Saver-type extensions.

Now I understand it better, thank you for explanation. It is probably really needed.
Answer you suggested is surely true. Nevertheless I would appreciate some kind of solution. Aside from that problem, even if i hadn't any session saver I wouldn't be quite happy if FF window was closed in any case by any extension.
From my point of view, if it is not too much work for you, maybe the option like ("Dont close FF window if only one tab is open") would be the best solution.
If it was there, I would check it and people who use it as you described it would leave it unchecked.
